answers.q: is glutamic acid the same as glutamine
answers.a: No. Glutamic acid (E620) is an amino acid, while glutamine is its amide derivative; they’re related but chemically distinct and serve different roles.

answers.q: is glutamate the same as glutamic acid
answers.a: They’re the deprotonated (glutamate) and protonated (glutamic acid, E620) forms of the same molecule; at typical physiological and food pH, glutamate predominates.

answers.q: is glutamic acid acidic or basic
answers.a: Acidic—glutamic acid has two carboxyl groups and is largely present as its negatively charged form (glutamate) at neutral pH.

answers.q: is glutamic acid the same as glutamate
answers.a: Yes—glutamate is the ionized form of glutamic acid (E620); which term is used depends on pH or whether it’s in a salt (e.g., MSG).

answers.q: are glutamate and glutamic acid the same
answers.a: Yes—they refer to the same substance in different forms: glutamic acid is the acid, and glutamate is its anion or salt.
